ratings.comment: He explaned everything very clear in lecture and was able to answer all my questions after class.  The homework took alot of time to complete and was not very benifitial in my opinion.  The exams where notacbly more difficult that the previous semesters and did not get curved.

Hanhart is awesome. His lectures flow very well, he does a great job of explaining abstract concepts, and is pretty funny/nice. Lots of homework, but it's all useful test prep. I had an A in the class before I stopped going to lecture/discussion, so just show up and do your work and you'll do well.
His lectures are very conceptual. To do well in the class definitely work through outside resources.

Professor Hanhart is very knowledgeable on this course and communicates that knowledge well to the students. This is a tough class with lots of homework, but I don't think it could get any better as far as professors go.
He is a great professor who really connects with the students
He rushed through a lot of the lessons and I felt like since we had people that already knew the content, he didn't spend much time explaining.

Hanhart is a phenomenal professor. He did a great job taking complex ideas from multi-variable calc and dumbing them down into real-world examples to make them much easier to understand. He also is just a very funny and easy going guy as well. Highly would recommend him to anyone who has the chance to take him. Easily one of my fav professors here.

Hanhart is hands-down the best math professor I've had. It is difficult to teach math at any level and Hanhart explained all of the multivariable concepts clearly and concisely. This is the first math class that I haven't needed to self study for. Unfortunately, like all of the Calc classes at Madison, 84% of the grade is composed of exams.

He overcomplicated so many concepts and I spent so much time outside of class teaching myself these concepts because I almost always left lectures confused. His lectures are very geared toward people who have already taken calculus and therefore have a better understanding of it and was very theory-based. I had a difficult time with this class.

He is a really funny guy but when it came to lectures they were not very informational. He would spend significant times on proofs when we didn't need to learn them for the tests. Exams were 84% of your grade, and lectures didn't exactly reflect practice problems. DO THE HOMEWORK! He is a lot better than other math profs. I heard

Professor Hanhart was a good professor teaching a tough class. The homework was lengthy and difficult, weekly discussion quizzes were easy, exams were extremely difficult and made up most of your grade. We were led to believe that the class is curved, however at the end of the semester he revealed that it is not curved. Hard class, good professor.

Calc 1 is a hard class anyway and I think out of the calc professors at UW he's one of the better ones. The course is very theorem heavy and apparently you don't use much of it beyond this class. The exams actually aren't too bad, usually there are no monster problems. There is a ton of homework though and it takes a few hours to get done.
He's a good teacher, but he's way too heavy on the terminology and makes everything way too complicated.

Linear algebra is a tough class, but I felt pretty lucky to have Hanhart. Exams are weighted very heavily, and lectures can have a lot of material. He was good at explaining; office hours were useful; class was organized; answered questions effectively. He's very passionate about the material.

Math 340 is a tough class. Hanhart is a good professor and teacher for that matter. I didnt use the textbook and still learned the concepts really well from his lectures alone. My only issues were I wish he had more office hours and the exams should have been allotted more time... but we are online so its hard to make it fair for everyone.

Grades are determined by 3 midterms and a final. Each exam is 3-4 questions with 3 points for each. Lose 1 point, you are down a letter grade. Test questions are nothing like what we learn in class. For every midterm, I watch the lectures and take notes and read the textbook and take notes and I still do terrible. Just don't take the class.

His exams were extremely hard. They were all theory based. I understood computations very very well, but he throws some very intuitive, abstract, and theoretical concepts on exams, and he does not give enough time at all for exams.

Test questions are out of 3 points. Most exams only have 3 questions. Make one mistake and you're in trouble. This professor is a nice guy but his class kills your GPA. Exams are brutal. VERY hard to get a C in this class.

Imagine a class where your grade is determined by a midterm worth 9 points. 1 point off? That's a B. 2 points off? Yup, you're at a C. Great guy and alright lecturer, TERRIBLE grading policies and grader. Does not care about your GPA, just your "ability". If you don't care about your GPA, take him. If not, RUN AWAY. Effort is useless for his exams.

Hardest class to pass at UW-Madison. Tests are graded out of 3 points. Make one mistake? Now you're at a 66%. I had a 3.8 GPA before coming into this class and couldn't pass this one. The content wasn't too bad but the way this professor grades is ridiculous.

Lectures were incredibly theory heavy, and not helpful in learning the material as there were very few practical examples given. There were a ton of homework assignments along with weekly exams and several quizzes a month. Doing the homework was the most useful way of learning and understanding the material to prepare for the exams.

I took this class in fall of 2020, completely online. There was no final/midterm, and your grade was made up of eight exams throughout the semester (answers turned in on Cengage and work turned in through canvas were separate grades). Not hard to get an A, and I never attended a lecture or discussion section past September.

Do not take his class. Run while you have chance. One of the worst professor ever and his test is terrible. Do not even bother studying for his test because they are nothing like classwork. So terrible and ruined my GPA.

Professor Hanhart is a solid math professor. One of the best Ive had at Madison. Hes smart and very friendly. I recommend going to his office hours, I always felt like I learned something afterwards. If youre having trouble with LaTeX you should look into editors like Mathcha.

Overall a good professor. My biggest gripe with the class was typing out every HW assignment in LaTeX, it was just tedious and time consuming. Also he has not great handwriting, but other than those things he is very nice and a good lecturer, he knows his stuff. Very helpful in office hours, one of his biggest strengths. Final was definitely fair.

Professor Hanhart is a funny personable guy but his exams and quizzes are so strange. He covers things really off topic of what was covered in class and most exams were honestly the same questions with some variation. It's not a difficult class but it is difficult to understand what is expected of you and how to prepare for exams.

Hanhart is funny and entertaining in class BUT spends half the class deriving formulas and spends very little time actually doing problems and teaching us the stuff that matters. He also gives weekly homework assignments that are way harder than the exams

Professor Hanhart is a phenomenal professor, and I'm pretty surprised by what some of these other reviews say about him. His lectures are very organized, he teaches concepts concisely and is great at intuitively explaining concepts. I would agree that his tests can be a bit challenging, but surely not out of reach. Made Calc 3 pretty interesting.

He stands on the board for like 5 minutes, gives like 4 problems for half of the lecture and sometimes goes over them. Most people think the tests are difficult, but if you study concepts it shouldnt be too bad. Overall he isnt the best lecturer and doesnt go over some concepts thatll be on the exams.

He is very knowledgeable but only would write the skeleton of proofs in class leaving you to fill in all the blanks. He didn't explain hard topics well and his homework and exam problems are extremely difficult. He was very unhelpful in office hours and would help much with understanding how to do the homework.

AVOID! Hanhart teaches extremely fast and writes so fast on the board that you can barely keep up. He told the class our midterm would be written by our first professor, as he came in as a temporary teacher halfway through the semester, but ended up writing his own midterm with problems that we had never seen before. Worst professor I have ever had

COMPLETELY DISREGARDED ALL OF THE PRACTICE WORKSHEETS WE DID IN DISCUSSION AND ALL OF THE PREVIOUS EXAMS WHEN WRITING AN EXAM FOR A CLASS HE HAD TAUGHT FOR ONLY A WEEK BEFORE. HE COULD'VE AT LEAST TOLD US WHAT TYPE OF PROBLEMS WOULD BE ON THE TEST.

To put it bluntly, Hanhart is the worst instructor I have ever had for any subject in my entire life on earth. Prepare to have your GPA ruined by this man. There is not even a point in studying for his tests as they're filled with information not practiced or taught in class and stuff that falls outside of the testable curriculum. Avoid at all cost

The worst professor I've ever had. He barely taught us anything in the lecture. Then, we'd have homework assignments and quizzes on material never learned. The exams were impossible, simply because you never knew what to expect. Overall, the topics in this course are easy, but you never knew exactly what you'd be tested over.

I took 521 with Prof Hanhart. one of the most fun, understanding and easy going Professors I've come across at UW. Keeps the class interactive, makes sure ppl are grasping the concepts. However, the grader Yunbai Cao is totally irrational and whimsical, gives grades by looking at names, putting a blot on everything that's good with this class.

Probably one of the most difficult classes I've taken so far. The concepts in the class are a bit abstract, so you really have to think about them outside of class. That being said, I thought his lectures were helpful but not enough to help you do well. DO THE HOMEWORK even though it isn't due because his exams are SUPER DIFFICULT.
The average GPA is 2.48. Only 13% A and 3% AB. C is more than B. F is more than AB. Although he is funny, you are not worth taking MATH 340 with him. Another professor has 40% A.

Good professor and clear lectures. However, the curve of this class is weird since he curves by section. The class average of the final was 65% and the average for midterms were around 75%. However, the A cutoff of my section was 91%, which is insanely high given the class averages. So pray that you don't land in the best discussion section.

To be honest, there was maybe once all semester that I came out of class feeling like I knew what was going on. I feel that the explanations he gave were unnecessarily confusing, and the slides were often just proofs (I believe the slides were not his even). The tests were very difficult with lots of definitions, textbook was horrible, do not recc.

Although Hanhart is a funny teacher and teaches the topics well, his exams are very challenging. His exams also do not coincide with the book, the practice problems in the book look completely different than his questions. Along with this he does not check his email. He also does nothing to help you in class. No hints or what he expects for tests.

Hanhart is a pretty solid teacher. Lectures are very useful, although sometimes he explains things in a more confusing way than necessary. It's not an easy class but overall he teaches the concepts pretty well and gives reasonably difficult exams. He is one of the funnier teachers I've had at UW, and can definitely bench press a serious amount.
Exams are somewhat difficult and I usually find theres lack of time while completing the exams. But his lectures are super awesome as he makes it quite engaging.

This professor is mostly not accessible outside of class, and not very caring. It seems like he put minimum effort into teaching this class, and he does not really care whether his students get a fair grade that reflects their effort. Additionally, he is not very good at lecturing this topic neither.
Prof Hanhart is a great lecturer! I liked this class much more than I thought I would and it really inspired me to take more math. Exams and homework were tough but not unexpectedly so.

The only math lecturer I have enjoyed listening to. Funny guy and keeps the class involved with practice problems in lectures. Homework is optional and I never really did it, but that forced me to read and understand the book examples before the tests.
HArdest Tests ever

This was a tough class, and he explained material in a very confusing and round-about way. The class was tough and definitely not curved enough. Hanhart is a funny guy though and is available for help if you need him, but I did not find his methods of explanation very helpful.

The best math professor I've had so far at UW-Madison. Always willing to take questions about things and lecture slides available. A lot of homework but he doesn't collect it so you get out what you put in. Very interesting lectures where you learn the material. The textbook used wasn't very helpful, most everything I learned was from the slides.

This was his first semester teaching 213. I took it expecting the historically easy Calc 2 class that's recommended for finance majors. He teaches it much differently than the previous professor, and it's near impossible to get an A with him. Absolutely would not recommend.

I have had him for 171&217 and he was fine. This semester I probably went to class a total of 10 times because he spends most of the class talking about theory which was irrelevant. I barely studied for the exams or quizzes and did okay but I took AP calc in high school. Homework is hard but quick. Exams have very low averages&should be curved more

This professor assumes students already have an in-depth background in calc, although this is a calc 1 class. Core concepts were not explained, and he uses abstract examples in class and on exams, which had extremely low averages. Even tutors for this class didn't know how to approach his questions, and the resources are not provided to do well.

I despised this class. I thought that it was poorly organized and made harder then it hard to be. If I had to do it over again I'd take 114 then 221. Hanhart is not great at teaching and writes confusing exams. Awful grading curve where only 11% ended up with As. Do not take this sequence if you're on the fence.

Hanhart is a great professor in lecture, but get ready for A LOT of homework that sometimes takes hours to complete. He makes the power lectures a little better with his humor, and is well understandable. The quizzes sometimes are tricky and the exams are relatively hard, but put in the work and you'll be fine. Minimal textbook use.

I managed to pass his class and actually learn something despite being frequently ill and kind of a slacker, so he must be doing something right. Not easy but totally worth it. Funny and engaging guy.
Prof. Hanhart is a funny dude, and a really good professor. Taught me things I didn't understand all throughout high school in matter of minutes. Class was pretty easy.

His personality is exactly like Oscar Isacc from ex Machina, though less crazy, he also looks like him. He's funny, super smart and very good at explaining things conceptually. Tests are brutal, he said not big on curving anything. No homework was nice, but all your grade is in the tests
In my opinion, he is a great professor and teaches well, makes sure you understand the concepts in lecture but makes difficult homework assignments and tests.

Professor Hanhart definitely made lectures entertaining, as well as easy to understand. He taught formulas by deriving them, which in my opinion makes them much easier to remember and understand rather than just being given them. He also effectively answered questions in lecture in a way where he wasn't talking down to students. Overall great guy

Good teacher, but the amount of homework gets annoying. He also takes an eternity to give you your grades back on exams. Overall a good choice for this class though.  Also the book is available legally on the UMich website

Very good lecturer, very easy to learn from. Uses slides so you don't have to wait for him to write things, and gives time for you to work and check over in-class problems. Though tests can be tricky.

He is a funny guy. It was he's 1st time teaching the primarily freshmen class. However, he did pretty well. His teaching really focused on proofs and knowing HOW you get equations rather than  when/how to use them. He is always welcoming to questions and doesn't make you feel stupid for asking them. Good guy.

The best professor I've had yet. The only math professor I've had that is somehow also super funny. Also really knowledgeable. Great at explaining things verbally although his slides had mistakes pretty often (which he would point out and fix later). Homework not graded (I never did it). Projects and tests were very reasonable.

I had to take this math for my CS major. I'm not crazy about math, but Prof. Hanhart made this course enjoyable! I really like his lecture style - we usually worked on examples in lecture. The quizzes and tests are fair, but make sure to keep up because it's really easy to fall behind! Would definitely recommend Prof. Hanhart for 340.

In class, He's definitely hilarious. Favorite Math professor yet. Tells great stories, usually not about Math.   Tests were long, very long, and hard to prepare for, often with wildcard problems, from Calc I. REALLY go over your notes and practice the worksheets. He is great in class, but expects a lot. Really likable guy, but demanding class.
Professor Hanhart is a great combination of passion and competence, something that is unfortunately rarely seen in a lot of teachers.

The laziest professor I have ever had.  Rarely showed up on time(if he showed up at all), quizzes and homework graded weeks after they were turned in, and we barely made it thru half the book when the other sections finished it.  Class was a waste of time.  Tests and quizzes were very easy.  Skip the class, read the book and get a good grade.

sarcastic and sassy, but so intelligent. he goes through slides kind of quickly, but they're always posted. there arent always good explanations on the slides (he talks) so going to lecture is more beneficial. Oh no you have to go to lecture? no biggie, he makes it entertaining with his comments. always willing to help and answer questions
He is THE MAN! Makes class super enjoyable and is crazy funny.

To all the people on here that say he's a bad professor because his class is hard, you're wrong. It's math. Of course it is hard. However, if you are going to take calc classes, Hanhart is the guy to do it with. He's hilarious and makes lectures interesting. Do the homework (ALL OF IT) and try to understand it and you will do fine in the class

Super funny and nice. Also very helpful, was going through some tough times and was super understanding about it. Lectures are never boring because he likes to crack jokes. Only downside is his tests are very conceptual and tough.
His lectures were interesting. BUT, his exams were soooooooooo hard.

Overall Hanhart was a good professor. His lecturing would often focus more on theory than on computation, which is not the best when teaching first semester calculus, but other than that he was fine. The tests were hard, but straight forward. I would take him again.

This was the hardest class that i took last semester and to be quite frank, I hated it. Hanhart knows what he's talking about but he lectured to freshman as if we we're seniors taking calculus. His test we're more theoretical and not computation and clear cut. Pretty arrogant and office hours are not useful at all. Avoid him if u struggle with math

I struggle with math, especially Calculus, and his class increased my confusion. I found the lectures difficult to follow and the practice/homework nearly impossible at times. I went in to his office hours once and found it very unhelpful. If math comes easily, then this would probably be a good class for you. If not, try to find another class.
I like his hilarious lecture!!  He gave many examples when he talked new concept, which was pretty helpful.
Tests are hard. He teaches really well. He tries to make the lectures a fun time.

He is a decent teacher and knows what he is talking about. However, he is the most arrogant man I have ever met. His office hours are unhelpful because you feel like he is talking down at you. Even when you understand the material, he acts as if it is common knowledge and makes you feel small. Overall, do not recommend for someone new to Calculus
His tests are extremely hard and students are given very less time to finish them. His explanations are detailed and he's an extremely knowledgable professor .
